segments.text: This is a test.

Today's interview, April 1, 1980, is with Dr. Patton Burns, retired professor of veterinary medicine and former head of the Department of Veterinary Physiology and Pharmacology, also the author of a little booklet entitled Veterinary and Medicine at Texas A&M, 1958 to 1978.
There we go.
Okay, it's working.

Today's interview, April 1st, 1980, is with Dr. Patton Burns, retired professor of veterinary medicine, former head of the Department of Vet Physiology and Pharmacology, and author of this fine little book, Veterinary Medicine at Texas A&M 1958 to 1975.
Let's talk about your background first.
You're a native Texan.
Yes.
You tell me when you were born.
I was born in Cuero, Texas, October 16, 1901.
Can you tell me about your early life, about your parents?
Well, we lived several miles, about four miles north of Cuero on the Cuero-Yoakum Road in DeWitt County.
And I grew up there.
I went to school in Cuero for 11 years.
Of course, we didn't have the 12th grade then.
And I graduated there in 1919.
Came here as a freshman in September.
And other than about 10 months in Beaumont, I've been here ever since, since September 1919.
What did your father do?
Did he have a ranch out there?
He was a farmer, rancher.
He was?
Cattle?
Well, mostly mules.
He was a mule breeder.
And he had a bunch of mares and a jack.
but he bought quite a few mules.
He'd go down the Rio Grande Valley and buy mules, and well, any place he could buy them in the state.
But my brother, two brothers, older brothers, we had two of them.
One was a physician, the other two were stockmen and ranchers.
If he ever bought some horses or cattle in these deals, well, he'd turn them over to them.
But he had some black cattle, mules.
And my brother had some reds.
And they were always competing with one another.
I think they just kept them as hobbies.
But mostly, I'd say 75% farming and 25% ranching.
Well, I knew him.
He had ranched before then.
Oh, by the time I left in 1919, he was turning out quite a bit of the farm into grazing land.
So he was going back to that.
What was he growing?
Cotton mostly.
That was a cash crop.
A little corn and maize.
He planted gumes between the corn rows.
He was the first one in the county to build any terraces.
He came to A&M.
These formerly short courses of Congress, as they called them then.
He'd pick up an idea here and there, so he decided to terrace.
Then he was the first one to plant legumes between the corn rows, and he more than doubled his yield.
But he was a diversified farmer.
He liked to do both.
Why did he go down to Rio Grande for the mules?
Is that the best area in that particular town to buy mules?
Well, he could buy smaller mules down in that part of the country.
around Final Furious and around that area.
I believe Hepburnville, below George West, between that and the border.
But they were smaller mules.
Well, what was the advantage of having a smaller mule?
Well, they sold better in that county.
These big Missouri mules, you'd very seldom see those.
They were used by contractors more.
That was before the days of the tractor.
You'd find these big mules on these road contractors' work.
How many acres are in this ranch?
Oh, around a thousand.
Really?
Well, about close to 900 in one, and about 250
mother's old place down between Quora and Victoria.
Did he have any help besides two boys, three boys, three sons?
Well, they were the three sons older than I were half-brothers.
They were two sets of children.
His first wife died when she was about 35.
Then he married
Anna Wright from Thomaston, that is between Queroa and Victoria.
And she had inherited some property from her on the old side.
Charles Lockhart was her grandfather.
And she had inherited some from her mother.
And the original, one of the Stephen F. Austin grants.
I still own my share.
Do you really?
How much is that?
Oh, a little over 100 acres.
And it goes all the way back to the Austin grants?
Oh, yes.
On your father's side, too?
No on her side, my father's are more recent.
I think my mother's goes back to about 1820s and the 20s.
My father's into the 1830s I think.
So her people were here before his.
And your father's forefathers came in the 1830s and lived in that same area ever since?
Well, I've got one nephew who bought the place, the place that my father and mother, where we lived, between Cuero and Yoakum.
And he owns it now.
And his father had some ranching north of there, close to Yoakum.
He owns that, and also he inherited some from his mother.
So on that Cuero-Yoakum road, he has about half of that.
land on both sides between those places.
Can you tell me about your upbringing as a young man?
Well, no, just the usual eleven grades and working in the summers on the farm.
My father employed to take students and I think merely
so they could keep me some company, but he'd usually employ larger and stronger ones than I, and I think with a purpose.
I know two football boys, two of them went to the University of Texas.
One was an outstanding star at the University of Texas.
And they would do it for exercise, for conditioning in the summer, work old summer.
Some of the boys would pick six or eight or 10 boys would come out there right after holidays, and some of them worked too fast.
Some of them would last till 12 o'clock the first day.
Some through the first day.
Some checked out one or two the next two or three days.
Usually end up about three of us left for the summer.
What did he pay them?
I think they usually go in price a dollar a day.
The blacks and the Mexicans around, they got the same thing.
Did he hire blacks and Mexicans also?
He hired who he could get?
Mexicans mostly.
But when it came to hog killing time, the Negroes were there too.
How many, did he add hogs in too?
Oh yes, oh yes, we'd kill eight or ten at a time.
That's pretty interesting.
Did you ever get any time off and when you did, what did you do on your time off?
I didn't know what a vacation was then.
I spent on the farm to my advantage because I recall once staying to football and they
those interested in football practice.
I think it was in eighth or ninth grade, and I stayed for football practice and got it home by dark.
That was the last time.
He said, who's gonna feed those hogs and milk those cows?
We were milking seven cows.
And he said, I'm not gonna do all your work for you.
He said, you help me, but said, who's gonna take care of those hogs?
You can't do some of that work
Effectively after dark.
He said, here you are at dark before you got home.
See, I rode horseback.
By the time I got home, the sun was down, gone.
He says, it's more important doing this farm work than it is playing down on the football field.
So that was the last time I went out.
What were your favorite subjects in high school?
I think math was my favorite.
I had a little more difficulty with it, and I liked history, and it went right through me.
And easy to come, easy to go.
But I particularly liked Texas history and American history.
In fact, I had those under
Walter P. Webb by now, or at least that was after he left there.
Then he went to San Antonio.
He stayed in Coro only about one or two years.
His, Buck Shewitz, I'm sure you've heard of him, the artist.
Buck's father was chairman of the school board.
And he was responsible for getting Mr. Webb at that time.
And then he went on to the University of Texas and, of course, gained considerably fame.
But I thoroughly enjoyed my experience with him.
Oh, I liked English and manual training.
I don't know of any subjects I didn't like.
Would you consider yourself a good student in high school?
Oh no, I'd say ordinary.
Getting back to your father's farm or ranch, was it profitable?
Well I used to remember him say that he would make an outstanding crop
once every seven years in farming.
That's the cycle, and he just enough to stay in, but I don't remember him having any difficulty in helping the renters.
They were on halves, they rented on half and half, and he would
for the dry goods and the groceries and the drug bills during the year, and then they would pay him back when they got the cotton in the summer.
And I don't know if I remember when he was really in difficulty, but what I mean by an outstanding crop that seventh year.
Yeah, yeah.
But, yes, I think it was profitable.
They were always buying up the land here and there and adjoining the place, adding to it.
In other words, he had sharecroppers then?
Well, yes.
They had the house, but he stood for their bills during the year.
I remember we all got a 10% discount.
I could go in.
He told me one day that he was, I met him on the road, and he said, this is the last day I want to see you wearing a cap.
I think I was about the sixth grade.
He said, tomorrow you go by, he designated the store, and get your hat.
I think he'd already picked out the hat.
It was a Stetson.
Oh, really?
So I've worn hats ever since.
Did they have boots for you, too?
No, my brother was the one that wore the boots.
The boots were a little too expensive for me.
But I never saw my brother on a pair of shoes until we went by.
He was 25 years older than I.
He was the oldest one in the family.
My wife and I went by to see him down in Jim Wells County at Alfred.
That's between Alice and George West.
So I said, Tom, what in the world are you doing wearing shoes?
I said, that's the first pair of shoes I've ever seen you wear.
And he says, hey, don't have the shoemaker I used to have, Mr. H. Boney.
And he and his son both got boots.
And as long as he lived, they got boots there.
But he says they can't fit me anymore, and he was very particular.
But I remember as a child, about three years old, I went out in the old manger there, and a pair of his boots, a hard, had been sewn away.
After they got in the mud, they were about worn out.
They were hard from being wet and mud, but I had to put them on.
And I put one of them on, and there were three stinging scorpions in the bottom of that.
And I couldn't get the things off.
And I stomped, and I couldn't kill them.
So a Negro woman came and finally got my foot out.
But that was my own.
Were you sick?
No.
Really?
It didn't really bother me much.
No kidding.
Not nearly as bad as a red ant.
Oh, yeah.
Sit down on one of those hills.
Tell me about the renters.
How many did you have, and could you tell me something about the system that your father had with these renters?
Oh, I recall six or seven Mexican houses that they had on the place.
I have to say
He figured around 40 acres to a man, but frequently the wives and the children did a lot of work.
Some of them would farm 80 acres and some 120 acres.
Depends on the size of the families.
Let's see, one, two, three, one, three of them in a row, three, four, five, six.
I remember six.
I said seven.
I remember six.
And then I had another one down at Palmerston on the Victoria.
That would be seven.
And the way he worked it was they grow the crops and then at the end of the year split things up 50-50?
Yes, in other words, he supplied the mules and the feed and everything.
But he got his money first in the fall when they sold.
Sometimes they'd be in the third or the fourth bale before this sharecropper would get a cent.
Or he might let them have a little.
But when they first got their first money that was theirs, they'd go by the meat market and get meat, lean meat, and make jerky out of it.
And you could go down there and see it on the barbed wires and the clothes lines up and down these houses.
They'd like to make that jerky.
But I interpreted for, when he had to leave, I remember he went in federal court, called it a federal court in Houston.
And he was gone a few days and asked me to sell the cotton.
The merchants couldn't talk Mexican, and he had some runners who couldn't talk English.
And so, oh, and the doctor, who happened to be my uncle, came out of the place.
I always did the interpreting for him.
He couldn't talk a word of Spanish.
I'd talk Spanish before I could talk English.
And being around these renters, in fact, my father employed a woman who had taught school in Mexico.
And he told her, not a word of English around that child.
I was about three or four, three, I guess.
And she, her husband was employed, but he, just as a laborer.
And she would come and help my mother with the dishes.
And then she'd take me home and spend the day.
And by the time I got back, it was about dark.
So I got to hear very little English.
And so first thing you know, I was talking Spanish, and I could handle it much better than I could English.
I talked to them before I could English.
It's easier than English, much easier.
And when I started first grade school, I guess I was six, and when the teacher would ask me a question, I'd start answering in Spanish, and I just, it was natural for me.
And all the kids got to laughing,
I could answer it faster in Spanish, because the words would come easier.
And then I started to have to, that's the way I started learning English, was in the first grade.
It was Aunt Lady?
Well, my mother and sister, and she taught school, and we were both going to school at the same time through the fourth grade.
I went with her.
But...
My mother never did try to talk it, and she got a little bit impatient and disgusted with some of them, and come up there and said, no entiendo, that I don't understand, in other words.
And she couldn't make them understand, and she called me.
But I liked it.
It gave me an entrance to these Mexicans and oh, I, when they'd have a wedding or anything like that, I got invited.
I went and I remember my father would not allow drinking nor gambling on the place.
When he ever got one, he found it drinking.
He'd get rid of it.
He didn't like these mechs and talk English.
He says, when they get up, these renters, when they get up and talk English too much, they don't make good farmers.
They don't know too much.
He did it jokingly.
But I ran into a poker game.
I think they were using grains of corn instead of the actual money.
But they were gambling.
It was on a Sunday.
And they're all old.
stopped when I walked into the room.
And I walked through the house just like the kids.
So I never did tell on those Mexicans and of course they knew it and so I was really accepted after that.
When did this renter system stop or when did it end?
Oh, I think it was still going half and half where the landowner would supply the things.
And they also had renters or sharecroppers who worked on third and fourth.
I believe that was right offhand, I don't remember which of the third.
One was on corn and the fourth was on cotton, just opposite.
But the one down at Thomaston, close to Guadalupe River, between Cora and Victoria, my mother's place, that was on 3rd and 4th.
And they'd make a good drop, they'd haul it up there to home, or either he'd buy it from my father, but the shack proper owned his own teams.
But that place always paid for itself.
Is the system still functioning today?
I don't know.
There are very few farms, nearly all grassland now, grazing land.
Okay, okay.
When you were about 16, the United States declared war on Germany, and there are a lot of German
German, people of German descent in Texas.
Do you remember any anti-German feelings during the war in your last year or two?
Oh yes, in fact I was, Cuero was, Cuero, Yorktown, Nordheim, Hallettsville, Schillenberg, Brenham, all Germans, Germans.
There were a few checks up around Holheim between Cuero and Gonzales.
And there were a few Polish people at Sweet Home between Yoakum and Hollisville.
But outside of that, nearly all Germans.
The checks have increased greatly.
I still take that quarrel record.
It comes out twice a week.
And as long as my sister was living until 78,
I didn't take it, because she always would write to me and give me the news.
But since then, I've been taking it, and oh, nearly all German names.
Occasionally there's a Smith and a Brown and a Jones.
And I have one nephew in Quirrell, and I have one in Yoakum.
And I very, very seldom see anything about the name Burns anymore.
And oh.
See, my father had four brothers and five sisters.
There were ten in the family.
Burns is all over the county.
It's just reversed here.
I used to be the only Burns in the Bryan College Station telephone directory.
Now, there's a terrific column of them.
And the former students, in the former students,
A directory.
I had two cousins who finished here.
And, oh, and a nephew.
And I guess there must have been about six or eight Burnes' in there.
And now there's about two whole columns of them.
And lots of Burnes' students and a lot of people who live here by that name, too.
Blacks and whites.
Why do you think that is?
I don't know.
I don't know.
Getting back to the war, could you tell me about some of this anti-German or pro-German cinema?
Well, only I was in school with one boy who was a German sympathizer.
His father was a saloon keeper, a good man.
But these boys, there were two boys and I think one sister,
And the one I was in, he had a temper.
And somebody hurt him one day, and he was talking about when Germany was going to defeat America and all of that stuff.
And I tell you, the kids really did resent it.
And it was very anti-German.
And I noticed a change.
I kind of felt sorry for the youngster.
But I never heard anymore.
I think they moved to Houston.
But the mother, one reason they resented them, because this boy's grandmother lived with them, lived there for years, and she couldn't talk a word of English.
And I think all of them talked German when they got home.
And other people didn't like that.
Oh, I think...
I think we accused them unjustly.
That's why I said that in a state of anger.
But I never did resent him.
I spoke to him when I saw him, but that was about as close as I ever got to him.
But I could notice in the classroom the attitude of the other kids.
youngsters can be pretty mean.
Oh, they can, yes, they certainly can.
Why'd you come to Texas A&M in 1919, wasn't it?
Yes, my father took me to the train and he says, what course are you going to take?
I came here because he was such a firm believer in the school.
And because he had taken some of these short courses during the summer?
Yes, well, his nephew,
My first cousin was head of the animal husbandry department at that time.
Oh, really?
John C. Burns.
He was in class in 1905, I believe, and A.C. Burns finished in 1907, and then went to Ohio State and studied by doing medicine.
And then Douglas Burns, who was later general manager of the Pitchfork Ranch, graduated in 16.
So those three brothers came here, and they all did so well.
And my father just, for one thing, he tried to send those.
Now, I had one brother who went to Vanderbilt to study medicine.
But the other two that were ranchers, especially Tom, he played hooky, and I doubt if he went beyond second or third grade, and probably the best businessman in the whole family.
And just a self-made man, so to speak.
But he sure didn't get it out of school.
And he was a huckleberry thing.
But I remember when my father and my mother were getting married, my aunt, she was an advisor for the family.
Everybody would have problems, they'd go to Aunt Ella.
And she told my mother, she says, Anna, you're going to have trouble with Tom.
That's the oldest brother of mine.
You're going to have trouble.
